Executive Summary



Odfjell Terminals (Charleston), LLC; 1003 East Montague Avenue, North Charleston, South Carolina 29405



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



At Odfjell Terminals (Charleston), LLC (OTC) we are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes in a safe and responsible manner.  We use a combination of accidental release prevention programs and emergency response planning programs to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public as well as protection of the environment.  This document provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that we have designed and implemented, including:



A description of our facility and the storage and transfer of substances regulated by EPA's RMP regulation



    *An overview of our accidental release prevention programs

    *A five-year accident history for accidental releases of chemicals regulated by EPA's  RMP rule

    *An overview of our emergency response program

    *An overview of planned improvements at the facility to help prevent accidental chemical releases from occurring and adversely affecting our employees, the public, and the environment.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES



Our public marine terminal stores and transfers a variety of chemicals.  The facility stores the chemicals in pressurized tanks and transfers them to and from various transportation modes including tank truck, rail car, barges, and ships.  The processes are storage and transfer only.  The storage and transfer currently only consist of flammable storage and transfer processes.



The systems for storage and transfer of other flammables and all toxics are the same basic design and use the same procedures.



We have identified the following flammable chemical that has the potential to cause off-site consequences in the event of a substantial accidental release: isoprene.



Our accidental release prevention programs and our contingency planning efforts h

hat we are meeting our own high standards for accident prevention.



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



Odfjell Terminals (Charleston) is a new facility, with operations beginning in January 2014.  Prior to OTC purchase of the terminal, the property was a Brownfields site.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The terminal employs several means of spill/release and fire control.  Located throughout the terminal are portable fire extinguishers, rated ABC that comply with OSHA and NFPA standards for portable fire extinguishers.  Hydrants and water hoses are located throughout the terminal and are available for hookup by the local fire department.  Furthermore, we coordinate our emergency response plans with all the local emergency planning commissions, of which OTC is an active member.



Spill/release control equipment is located throughout the terminal.  The tank farm sits within a containment berm, the rail and tanker truck loading areas have spill pans which are plumbed to the wastewater treatment plant.



Protective clothing is available for employees involved in any cleanup operations.  



OTC has contracted with Moran Environmental Recovery (MER) and HEPACO to respond to spills/releases at their facility.  MER is nationally recognized for their emergency spill response capabilities.  Under the United States Coast Guard's (USCG) Oil Spill Removal Organization (OSRO) program, MER holds a WCD3 (Worst Case Discharge) classification in all Eastern Captain of The Port Zones.  Their spill response capabilities satisfy planning and response requirements of the Oil Pollution Act of 1990 (OPA-90).



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



As a new facility, OTC utilizes the latest technology, including automated scales and meters to prevent overfills.  



OTC is planning to implement a certified management system audited and certified by a third party.  In addition, a procedure and safety training review matrix is being implemented.
